channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: John Cantlie, British Hostage, Said to Appear in ISIS Video From Kobani
item.description: Mr. Cantlie, a photojournalist abducted two years ago, is depicted as saying that the battle for the town on the Turkey-Syria border is “nearly over.”
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Guangzhou Turns to Mosquito-Eating Fish to Help Control Dengue Outbreak
item.description: The move has prompted criticism from some experts, who suggest it could upset the ecological balance in Guangdong waterways.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Mosquito fish, seen here in an aquarium in Virginia, are being deployed in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou to help fight dengue fever.

item.title: Sectarian Wedge Pushes From Syria Into Lebanon
item.description: Outbreaks of fighting in Lebanon have heightened fears that the civil war in Syria is spilling over the border, threatening the country’s fragile stability.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of a local patrol in the mainly Christian town of Ras Baalbek, Lebanon. Shiites and Christians in the valley are on edge.

item.title: Japanese Village Grappling With Wartime Sins Comes Under Attack
item.description: Ultranationalist cyberactivists have menaced the village of Sarufutsu over a memorial to Korean laborers who died building an airfield there.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Koichi Mizuguchi, the architect who first heard about the Koreans from the village postmaster, helped organize three excavations of the grave site.

item.title: Efua Dorkenoo Dies at 65; Key Foe of Genital Cutting in Africa, Middle East
item.description: She helped lead a successful 30-year campaign against the tradition of genital cutting of girls and women, mainly in Africa and the Middle East, by casting the practice as a human rights violation.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

item.title: Ford Family Loses Hold on City Hall in Toronto
item.description: John Tory, a center-right candidate for mayor, defeated Mayor Rob Ford’s brother, who had replaced him on the ballot.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Syria: Verdict in Doctor’s Death
item.description: The family of a British doctor who died last year in a Syrian prison claimed vindication Monday after a jury in London determined that he had been unlawfully killed.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Jian Ghomeshi, CBC Radio Host, Is Fired in Sex Case
item.description: Mr. Ghomeshi, the former host of “Q,” contends the sexual acts were consensual and is suing the Canadian Broadcasting Company, claiming breach of confidence.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Ari Mintz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jian Ghomeshi filed suit against the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, claiming breach of confidence and defamation.

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Suicide Bomb Kills Scores in a Town Seized From ISIS
item.description: A suicide bomber driving a Humvee packed with explosives drove into a security checkpoint for Iraqi troops and Shiite militiamen south of Baghdad on Monday, killing at least 38, officials said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Terrorism Bill Unveiled
item.description: The government of Prime Minister Stephen Harper introduced an antiterrorism bill on Monday that was to have been brought before lawmakers the day a gunman stormed Parliament.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Lithuania Offers Example of How to Break Russia’s Grip on Energy
item.description: A floating factory for converting liquefied natural gas into the burnable variety represents a direct challenge to the Russian way of doing business.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: The floating natural gas terminal Independence arriving in Klaipeda, Lithuania, on Monday.

item.title: Art Review: The Picasso Museum Reopens in Paris
item.description: The Picasso Museum in Paris has reopened at more than twice its previous size, but the vast collection is arranged in a choppy, idiosyncratic way.
item.dc:creator: By HOLLAND COTTER
item.media:credit: Ed Alcock for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Picasso Museum in Paris has reopened after a renovation that more than doubled its size.

item.title: Wish to Do More in Ebola Fight Meets Reality in Liberia
item.description: Health workers in Liberia and elsewhere in West Africa are finding they have to ration care, operating under constraints they often find frustrating.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A relative covered the head of Garmai Sayon, 23, as she returned to her village of Mawah, Liberia, after recovering from Ebola.

item.title: Memo From Paris: A Capital of the Arts Is Forced to Evolve
item.description: Economic troubles are clouding Paris’s role as a cultural beacon as France shifts from state funding and management of the arts toward a greater role by the private sector.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:description: The Louis Vuitton Foundation, a new museum in Paris, was designed by Frank Gehry and showcases the collection of the billionaire Bernard Arnault. The privately funded museum cost $135 million.

item.title: Arseniy Yatsenyuk and Petro Poroshenko Solidify Stances
item.description: The preliminary results solidified the authority of a government that, despite European backing, has been unable to suppress a pro-Russian separatist movement.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Ukrainians read newspapers at a metro station on Monday in Kiev.

item.title: Islamist Party in Tunisia Concedes to Secularists
item.description: Nidaa Tounes has won the largest number of seats in the election, defeating its main rival, the Islamist party Ennahda, according to two analyses of results.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Brazil Vote Highlights a Rift Linked to Economics
item.description: President Dilma Rousseff, who was re-elected on Sunday, has signaled changes that could bring a shift away from policies that have created anger in Brazil’s business establishment.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Minority Life in Israel
item.description: Palestinian Israelis face a daily battle against official discrimination and casual hatred.
item.dc:creator: By RULA JEBREAL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Considers Reducing Number of Crimes That Carry Death Penalty
item.description: The move is part of a long-term trend that has seen a decline in executions, though China still leads the world in the number of people put to death annually.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: She Xianglin being escorted out of a court in Hubei Province on April 13, 2005, following his acquittal for the murder of his wife, who turned up alive after he had served 11 years in prison.

item.title: Human Rights in Iran Worsen, U.N. Investigator Says
item.description: The investigator, Ahmed Shaheed, said executions and oppression of women have increased, even as Iran’s president seeks rapprochement with the West.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Attack Punctuates Taliban’s Advances in an Afghan Province
item.description: Four insurgents disguised as police officers killed eight and wounded 10 others in government offices in the capital of Kunduz Province.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Afghan security officials at the scene of a suicide bomb attack that targeted the office of a local attorney general on Monday in Kunduz, Afghanistan.

item.title: Netanyahu Expedites Plan for More Than 1,000 New Apartments in East Jerusalem
item.description: The construction in the Jewish neighborhoods of Ramat Shlomo and Har Homa was expected to draw international condemnation and exacerbate fissures in the governing coalition.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A construction site at a new housing project in annexed Arab east Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: South African Union Breaks From A.N.C. as Alliance Frays Further
item.description: The National Union of Metalworkers said it would break with the African Nation Congress and form a new socialist political party.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Working to Heal, in Israeli Town With a Deep Arab Wound
item.description: Reuven Rivlin, Israel’s new president, visited the site of an infamous 1956 massacre, with the goal of healing Jewish-Arab relations and urging tolerance.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: In Video, Ottawa Gunman Spoke of Political Motives
item.description: While the police did not release the video, an official said it provided persuasive evidence that the attack was motivated by the gunman’s ideology.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: A ceremony at an N.H.L. game in Ottawa on Saturday paid tribute to the Canadian soldiers who were killed last week there and in a separate attack in Quebec.
